Salamis it, Alexandria harbonr. Thia is one of the fleet of rteamere be'oi ging to ihe Limassol Steam Navigation Company, which was founded by Messrs. Pilavaohi in 1905 in order to develop the commercial and passenger traffic between Egypt and Cyprus.
The compauy started with a capital of £20,000, which waa subscribed hy the members of tho Pilavaohi family and a nui of Greek merchants interested in the export ard import trade between their island and this country. A few months ago tbe capital waa increased to £50,000, whioh was entirely subscribed by the original shareholders.
The company only began running the steamers of its Egypt-Cypros lice doting this summer. The fleet at present consists of the Lefkosia (1,400 tons, 11 knots), the Cypros (2,21 0 tons, 10 knots), and the Salamis (1,500 tons, 15 knots.) The last vessel was purchased only six weeks ago from the Aberdeen Line and used to ran between Aberdeen and London. Tho company has a regular weekly departnre on Tnoedays from Alexandria and on Fridays and Wednesdays in alternate weeks respectively from Limassol. All the steamers tonoh at Port Said. The Salamis and Lefkosia are lor the passenger service, while Ihe Cyprus is far oargo ; all these boats are British made, having been purchased io England. The company is contemplating buying another passeoger steamer of 4,000 tons io England, and will from time to time make farther additions to their fleet as the trade develops.
Tbe greater part of the trade between Egypt and Cyprus will, the oompany believe, fall into its hands, as the local Greek traders in Egypt and Cypras, who are interested in the trade between the two ooontries, are shareholders. The Government ol Cypros give nnml subvention of £5,000 to the oom-
pany for carrying the mails.
Among the projects of the company is one for starting a subsidiary Hotel Treat which develop the hotel facilities thronghont
Cypres and by building up-to-date hotels on Mount Troodos and in other resorts in that beantitnl island, will attraot tourists thither.

Having, under Mme Hadiog's auspices, gone through an exhaustive study of tho eternal triangle in all its aspects, it is something of a rebel to turn to so admirables drama as Sudermann's "Stein unter Steinen,"—to turn, that is to say, from romsnee to reality. For it is reality, or rather realism, that forms the essence of the play. It contains, properly speaking, only one problem, bnt one which ‘ gives furiously to think," namely the question whether Zarncke, in employing discharged conviot», ia right ia appealing to what little bononr they may cr may not have hy placing them in positions of trost, and snffsring accordingly. For tbe rest the drama atonnda in unique pictures of human nature. Take any one of tbe men or women whom Snder-mann so excellently portrays. No sooner are we introduced to them than we can tell a1mo>t to a certainty what lies btlore them ; no character is nntrne to itself; each pursues its coarse unswervingly. For instance, in Aot III., the stone-masons, accustomed to Biegler's oower ing demeanour, are astounded at his sadden outbreak, but we are not : crashed though he be by his five years' sentence lor manslaoghter, we have seen sufficient of him to know that he will be unable to endure Giittliogk'a insolence, Nur should it surprise us that Gottlingk, being thwarted, will seek his revenge, that Lore will at length abandon hope cf marriage wilh him, the father of her child, that Marie will eventu. ally yield to his allurements, that Strove, the philosophic old gaol bird, will betray tbe trost placed iu him, that, finally, Biegler, whose disinterested motives reoall Bernard Shaw's "Devil's Disciple," will at last overcome the scruples of his fsllnw-worlcmen and chase away the shadows which haunt his past There was never a more consistent play and seldom a better constrooted one. Each character speaks and behaves exaotly aa might be expected nnder tbe circumstances, and thus the dramatic situations seldom take ns unawares. But ever fresh matter for serions thought is afforded as well as admiration for the skill wilh which the plot is unfolded. There was one slight jarring note, when Sudermann carries his realism a little too fir : Biegler, after his violent scene with Gottlingk, return» to finish bis glass of beer. Now, no donbt, yonr loyal German will as toon think of leaving bis beer untouched as of openly abusing the Kaiser or of sitting in a drafty room ; yet Biegler's action rankled.
As regard» the production of this play, on Satnrday, by Sig. G. Novelli's Italian company, we will only say that, although all did their best, the acting on tho whole was below'he standard required. Signori Novelli, Tettoni, and 8pinelli, respectively,as Biegler,Gh'tlingk, and Strove, did well enough. Sig. Greco's Zarncke was too stagay, but Siga. Vidali made a creditable Lore.
Any pleasure the play might have afforded us was entirely spoilt by the persistence of tbe prompter to make his tinny, rançons voioe carry not only to the aotors bnt over the whole theatre, despite tbe effort, of the audience and of Sig. Novelli himself to repress him. Otherwise tbe play was well reoeived.
